III.	Facility Identification

The Baxter facility is located at 1900 Highway 201 N in Mountain Home, Arkansas. Baxter is a hospital products and pharmaceutical manufacturer specializing in IV solutions and premixed drugs, IV infusion pumps and administration sets, parenteral nutrition, etc.

The NAICS code for the facility is 325412. The facility uses ethylene oxide for product sterilization, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. 

Two (2), 400 pound cylinders of ethylene oxide are connected to each sterilization vessel at all times. In Vessel 7 drum room there is one (1) sterilization vessel in use at one time and a capacity to store six (6) cylinders, for a total of eight (8) ethylene oxide cylinders or 3,200 pounds. In the new drum room, there are a total of six (6) sterilization vessels used at one time and a capacity to store six (6) cylinders, for a total of eighteen (18) ethylene oxide cylinders, or 7200 pounds. In addition, the total capacity of the outdoor storage facility is thirty (30) cylinders, resulting in a potential of 12,000 pounds of ethylene oxide in the outdoor storage facility. Therefore, the total potential quantity of ethylene on-site is approximately 22,400 pounds.

An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A.

V

I.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   However, as discussed throughout this document Baxter is continuously improving this program. 

This prevention program covers those processes that utilize ethylene oxide above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The PSM and RMP are evaluated, at least, every three (3) years in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

	Employee Participation  Baxter has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
	Process Safety Information  Baxter maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. 
	Process Hazard Analysis  Baxter has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented.
	Operating Procedures  Baxter has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operation

s, ensures they are properly maintained, and reviewed and certified annually. 
	Training  Baxter has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ethylene oxide process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems. 
	Management of Change  Baxter has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ethylene oxide process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented.
	Pre-Startup Review  Baxter has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ethylene oxide process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
	Mechanical Integrity  Baxter has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.
 
	 Contractor Qualifications  Baxter has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Baxter and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.
	Incident Investigation  Baxter has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of ethylene oxide is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  Th

is procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. No ethylene oxide releases have been reported within the past five (5) years.
	Compliance Audit  Baxter has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Baxter PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  
	Hot Work Permits  Baxter has developed a best management practice for hot work.

VII.	Five-Year Accident History

The Baxter facility has not experienced an accidental ethylene oxide release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.	Emergency Response Program

Baxter has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Baxter has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has interacted (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Mountain Home Fire Department. 

Baxter has coordinated their EAP with the Mountain Home Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing the agency with a copy of our EAP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Mountain Home Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilitys operations/processes and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Mountain Home Fire Department personnel.

 
Currently, Baxter does not have designated personnel as members of a hazardous materials response team. The facility will rely on response by the Mountain Home Fire Department and HAZMAT Team, in the event of an ethylene oxide release.

The facility utilizes a

windsock onsite to determine wind direction in the event of an ethylene oxide release and evacuation of the building.  The windsock is located on the EO Shed. 

The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for ethylene oxide is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is a paramount element of Baxter operations. Baxter recently conducted a process hazard analysis (PHA) of their ethylene oxide system and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that PHA. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Baxter.  

XI.	Management  System

Baxter has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.
